question: The 100-hour inspection required by Federal Aviation Regulations for certain aircraft being operated for hire may be performed by
answerA: persons working under the supervision of an appropriately rated mechanic, but the aircraft must be approved by the mechanic for return to service.
answerB: appropriately rated mechanics only if they have an inspection authorization.
answerC: appropriately rated mechanics and approved by them for return to service.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A 100-hour inspection of an aircraft that is operated for hire may be performed by an appropriately rated mechanic and approved by him or her for return to service.

question: A person working under the supervision of a certificated mechanic with an airframe and powerplant rating is not authorized to perform
answerA: repair of a wing brace strut by welding.
answerC: repair of an engine mount by riveting.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A 100-hour inspection is the only procedure listed in these alternatives that a person working under the supervision of an appropriately rated mechanic is not allowed to perform.|Only a mechanic holding the appropriate ratings can perform the inspection.

question: Certificated mechanics, under their general certificate privileges, may
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A properly certificated mechanic may perform a 100-hour inspection of instruments, but he or she may not make any repair or alteration to an instrument.

question: An Airworthiness Directive requires that a propeller be altered. Certificated mechanics could
answerA: perform and approve the work for return to service if it is a minor alteration.
answerB: not perform the work because it is an alteration.
answerC: not perform the work because they are not allowed to perform and approve for return to service, repairs or alterations to propellers.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A certificated mechanic with a powerplant rating is authorized to perform the work called for in an AD on a propeller that requires a minor alteration to the propeller. After complying with the AD, the mechanic can approve the propeller for return to service.

question: The replacement of a damaged vertical stabilizer with a new identical stabilizer purchased from the aircraft manufacturer is considered a
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The replacement of a damaged vertical stabilizer with a new identical stabilizer purchased from the aircraft manufacturer is a minor repair. A rule of thumb for determining whether a repair is minor or major is that if the part can be bolted on and not require any riveting or welding, the repair is minor. This rule of thumb might well have exceptions.

question: FAA certificated mechanics may
answerA: approve for return to service a major repair for which they are rated.
answerC: approve for return to service a minor alteration they have performed appropriate to the rating(s) they hold.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: FAA-certificated mechanics may approve for return to service a minor alteration they have performed appropriate to the rating(s) they hold. This privilege, of course, assumes that the mechanic understands the current instructions of the manufacturer and has the maintenance manuals for the specific operation concerned. A certificated mechanic is not authorized to supervise a 100-hour inspection.

question: A certificated mechanic with a powerplant rating may perform the
answerA: annual inspection required by the Federal Aviation Regulations on a powerplant or any component thereof and approve and return the same to service.
answerB: 100-hour inspection required by the Federal Aviation Regulations on a powerplant or any component thereof and approve and return the same to service.
answerC: 100-hour inspection required by the Federal Aviation Regulations on an airframe, powerplant or any other component thereof and approve and return the same to service.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A certificated mechanic with a powerplant rating is authorized to conduct a 100-hour inspection on a powerplant or any component thereof and approve the return to service of the same.

question: What part of the Federal Aviation Regulations prescribes the requirements for issuing mechanic certificates and associated ratings and the general operating rules for the holders of these certificates and ratings?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR Part 65, 'Certification: Airmen Other Than Flight Crewmembers' prescribes the requirements for the issuance of mechanic certificates and associated ratings and the general operating rules for the holders of these certificates and ratings.

question: A certificated mechanic shall not exercise the privileges of the certificate and rating unless, within the preceding 24 months, the Administrator has found that the certificate holder is able to do the work or the certificate holder has
answerA: served as a mechanic under the certificate and rating for at least 18 months.
answerB: served as a mechanic under the certificate and rating for at least 12 months.
answerC: served as a mechanic under the certificate and rating for at least 6 months.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A certificated mechanic shall not exercise the privileges of the certificate and rating unless, within the preceding 24 months, the Administrator has found that the certificate holder is able to do the work or the certificate holder has served as a mechanic of the certificate and rating for at least six months.

question: Under Title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations, what is the maximum penalty for falsification, alteration, or fraudulent reproduction of certificates, logbooks, reports, and records?
answerA: Ineligibility to receive any certificate or rating for one year.
answerB: Imprisonment for one year and a $5,000 fine.
answerC: Suspension or revocation of any certificate held.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.20 states that any person who falsifies or makes a fraudulent entry in a logbook, report, or record is subject to the suspension or revocation of any airman or ground instructor certificate or rating held by that person.

question: How long does the holder of a certificate issued under Part 65 have to notify the FAA after any change in permanent mailing address?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.21 states that within 30 days after any change in their permanent mailing address, the holder of a certificate issued under this part shall notify the Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration, Airman Certification Branch, Post Office Box 25082, Oklahoma City, OK 73125 in writing, of their new address.

question: How long is a mechanic certificate with airframe and/or powerplant rating(s) valid?
answerA: Until the holder is relieved of duties for which the holder was employed and certificated.
answerB: Until voluntarily surrendered, permanently revoked, or temporarily suspended.
answerC: 24 months after the holder has last exercised the privileges of the certificate.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.15 states that a mechanic certificate with airframe and/or powerplant rating is effective until it is surrendered, suspended, or revoked.

question: Why is a mechanic applicant issued a temporary certificate after successful completion of the required tests?
answerA: To allow for review of their application and supplementary documents.
answerB: So that a background check/ investigation may be completed.
answerC: Both of the other two choices.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.13 provides for a temporary certificate and rating effective for a period of 120 days to be issued to a qualified applicant, pending review of their application and supplementary documents and the issue of the certificate and ratings for which they applied.

question: What is the maximum duration of a temporary airman certificate?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.13 provides for a temporary certificate and rating effective for a period of 120 days to be issued to a qualified applicant.

question: When may an otherwise qualified mechanic who does not read, write, speak, and understand the English language be eligible to apply for a mechanic certificate?
answerA: When a special authorization has been granted by the Administrator.
answerB: When employed outside the United States by a U.S. air carrier.
answerC: When employed outside the United States.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.71(a)(2) requires that the applicant for a mechanic certificate be able to read, write, speak, and understand the English language, or in the case of an applicant who is employed outside of the United States by a U. S. air carrier, have their certificate endorsed 'Valid only outside the United States.'

question: Which of the following statements is true for a certificated and appropriately rated mechanic regarding repairs and alterations?
answerA: He or she may perform an airframe major repair or major alteration, but cannot approve the work for return to service.
answerB: He or she may perform airframe minor repairs and minor alterations and approve the work for return to service, but cannot perform an airframe major repair or major alteration.
answerC: He or she may perform an airframe major repair or major alteration and approve the work, but not the entire aircraft, for return to service.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR 65.81(a) states that a certificated mechanic may perform or supervise the maintenance, preventive maintenance or alteration of an aircraft or appliance, or a part thereof for which he or she is rated (but excluding major repairs to or major alterations of propellers, and any repair to, or alteration of instruments).|The mechanic must complete the FAA Form 337, filling in the compliance statement, but the person approving the work for return to service must hold an Inspection Authorization

question: (1) Certificated mechanics with an airframe rating may perform a minor repair to an airspeed indicator providing they have the necessary equipment available.|(2) Certificated mechanics with a powerplant rating may perform a major repair to a propeller providing they have the necessary equipment available.|Regarding the above statements,
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Statement 1 is not true. No certificated mechanic, regardless of his or her ratings, is allowed to perform minor or major repairs, or minor or major alterations to instruments. Statement 2 is not true. A mechanic holding a powerplant rating cannot perform major repairs or major alterations to propellers.

question: Who is responsible for determining that materials used in aircraft maintenance and repair are of the proper type and conform to the appropriate standards?
answerB: The owner or operator  of the aircraft.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: It is the responsibility of the person or agency (the certificated mechanic or the approved repair station) performing aircraft maintenance or making repairs to an aircraft, to make sure that all of the materials used in the maintenance or repair conform to the appropriate standards.

question: Which of these publications contains standards for protrusion of bolts, studs, and screws through self-locking nuts?
answerC: Aircraft Specifications or Type Certificate Data Sheets.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: AC 43.13-1B states that 'After the nut has been tightened, make sure that the bolt or stud has at least one thread showing past the nut.'

question: The replacement of a damaged engine mount with a new identical engine mount purchased from the aircraft manufacturer is considered a
answerA: major or minor repair, depending upon the complexity of the installation.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The replacement of a part such as an engine mount with a new, identical part obtained from the aircraft manufacturer is considered to be an airframe minor repair.

question: Who has the authority to approve for return to service a propeller after a 100-hour inspection?|1. A mechanic with a powerplant rating.|2. Any certificated repairman.|3. A non-certificated mechanic working under the supervision of a certificated mechanic with airframe and powerplant ratings.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A certificated mechanic holding a powerplant rating is authorized to perform a 100-hour inspection on a propeller and may approve the same for return to service.

question: Instrument repairs may be performed
answerB: by an FAA-approved instrument repair station.
answerC: on airframe instruments by mechanics with an airframe rating.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Repairs to an instrument, either major or minor repairs, may be performed only by an FAA-approved instrument repair station. The manufacturer of the instrument has this type of rating.

question: Which of the following terms is/are used to indicate specific measured distances from the datum and/or other points identified by the manufacturer, to points in or on the aircraft?|1. Zone numbers.|2. Reference numbers.|3. Station numbers.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Station numbers is a numbering system used on large assemblies for aircraft to locate stations such as fuselage frames. Fuselage Frame-Sta 185 indicates the frame is 185 inches from the datum of the aircraft. The measurement is usually taken from the nose or zero station, but in some instances it may be taken from the firewall or some other point chosen by the manufacturer.

question: What is the total capacitance of a circuit containing three capacitors in parallel with capacitances of .02 microfarad, .05 microfarad, and .10 microfarad, respectively?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Use the formula Ct = C1 + C2 + C3. When capacitors are connected together in parallel, the plate area of all the capacitors add together and the total capacitance is the sum of the individual capacitances. .02 + .05 + .10 = .170 uF.

question: Which of the following is Newton's first law of motion, generally termed the law of inertia?
answerA: To every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. If a force is applied to an object, the object will supply a resistive force exactly equal to and in the opposite direction of the force applied.
answerB: Force is proportional to the product of mass and acceleration. When a force acts upon a body, the momentum of that body is changed.
answerC: Objects at rest tend to remain at rest and objects in motion tend to remain in motion at the same speed and in the same direction, unless acted on by an external force.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Newton's first law explains that when an object is at rest, it tries to remain at rest. But when it is moving, it tries to keep moving in a straight line and will not speed up, slow down, or turn unless it is acted upon by an outside force. This tendency of the object to remain in its original condition of motion is called inertia.

question: What will a voltmeter read if properly connected across a closed switch in a circuit with electrical power on?
answerA: Voltage drop in the component(s) the switch is connected to.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: When a voltmeter is connected across a closed switch in perfect condition or a good fuse, it will read zero voltage. A voltage drop of up to 0.2 volts is acceptable with maximum circuit current flow through the switch.

question: In a sectional view drawing, what sections illustrate particular parts of an object?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A removed section illustrates particular parts of an object. It is similar to revolved sections, except it is placed at one side and, to bring out pertinent details, often drawn to a larger scale than the main view on which it is indicated.

question: How is a quality system assured?
answerC: By an internal reporting and auditing system.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A quality system must include procedures for planning, conducting, and documenting internal audits to ensure compliance with the approved quality system. The procedures must include reporting results of internal audits to the manager responsible for implementing corrective and preventive actions.

question: According to Dr. James Reason, there are two types of human failure which can occur. They are:
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: There are two types of failure which can occur - active and latent. An active failure is one in which the effects are immediate. A latent failure occurs as a result of a decision made or action takenlong before the incident or accident actually occurs.

question: Many areas of aviation have shifted their focus from eliminating error to
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The goal of the Maintenance Error Decision Aid (MEDA) is to investigate errors, understand root causes, prevent and manage accident (most of the factors that contribute to an error can be managed).

question: When we think of aviation safety in a contemporary way, human error is
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The "SHEL" model is another concept for investigating and evaluating maintenance errors. The acronym SHEL represents software, hardware, environment, and liveware -- with the human as the starting point for all.

question: All of the following are consequences of human error, except
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Human error is defined as a human action with unintended consequences. There are four consequences of human error: little or no effect, damage to equipment/hardware, personal injury, or catastrophic damage.

question: The positive aspects of human factor issues are referred to as the
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: |Subsequent to the development of the "Dirty Dozen," the "Magnificent Seven" list of human factors issues was developed and focused on positive aspects. These seven issues are: 1. We work to accentuate the positive and eliminate the negative. 2. Safety is not a game because the price of losing is too high. 3. Just for today - zero error. 4. We all do our part to prevent Murphy from hitting the jackpot. 5. Our signature is our word and more precious than gold. 6. We are all part of the team. 7. We always work with a safety net.

question: The SHEL model is another human factors tool. The goal is to determine not only what the problem is, but also
answerC: how many factors contribute to the error.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The goal of the SHEL model is to determine not only what the problem is, but where and why it exists.

question: The three types of human error are
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Human error is the unintentional act of performing a task incorrectly that can potentially degrade the system. There are three types of human error: 1. Omission: not performing an act or task. 2. Commission: accomplishing a task incorrectly. 3. Extraneous: performing a task not authorized.

question: Convert farads to microfarads by
answerA: multiplying farads by 10 to the power of 6
answerB: multiplying picofarads by 10 to the power of 6
answerC: multiplying microfarads by 10 to the power of 6
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: One farad is equal to 10^6 microfarads. Example: 2 farads is equal to 2 x 10^6 (2,000,000) microfarads.

question: Convert farads to picofarads by:
answerA: multiplying farads by 10 to the power of 12.
answerB: multiplying microfarads by 10 to the power of -12.
answerC: multiplying picofarads by 10 to the power of 12.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: One farad is equal to 10^12 picofarads. Example: 2 farads is equal to 2 x 10^12 (2,000,000,000) picofarads.

question: Which effect does not apply to the movement of electrons flowing in a conductor?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Current flowing through a conductor produces a magnetic field and also dissipates thermal energy.

question: What is the basic unit of electrical quantity?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The coulomb is the basic unit of electrical quantity. One coulomb is equal to 6.28 X 10^18 electrons.

question:
(1) Sketches are usually made with the aid of drafting instruments._x000D_
(2) Sketches are usually more complicated to make when using graph paper._x000D_
Regarding the above statements,
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Sketches are simple drawings made without the use of tools.  It is easier to do a sketch on graph paper where dimensions are easier to visualize without using tools such as a ruler.

question: What is used to indicate that a surface must be machine finished?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: By using finished marks a drawing identifies those surfaces that must be machine finished.

question: In order to locate wing and stabilizer frames, what numbering system is used?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Locations for fuselage frames in aircraft drawings are identified by station numbers.

question: When a Teflon hose has been in service for a time, what condition may have occurred and/or what precaution should be taken when it is temporarily removed from the aircraft?
answerA: The hose interior must be kept wet with the fluid carried to prevent embrittlement/deterioration.
answerB: The hose may become stiff and brittle if not flexed or moved regularly.
answerC: The hose may have developed a set, or have been manufactured with a pre-set shape, and must be supported to maintain its shape.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Teflon hoses develop a permanent set after having been in use for an extended period of time or may have been manufactured with a permanent set for the particular function, thus is should be supported to maintain its shape and prevent inadvertent straightening.

question: What is defined as a group of bits representing a complete piece of information?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A byte is composed of a group of 8 bits and represents a complete piece of information in a binary system.

question: Convert the binary number 00001111 to a whole number.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The binary number 00001111 is converted bit by bit into whole number: 1000 = 8; 0100 = 4; 0010 = 2; and 0001 = 1; thus the entire binary number equals 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 15 as a whole number.

question: (Refer to the Figure 66.) Solve the equation.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: -4 + 6 + 10^3(square root 1296) simplifies to 2 + 1,000(36), which equals 36,002.

question: A person installing a product, part, or appliance on a type certificated product must make certain that the item's records document the
answerA: product, part, or material meets FAA airworthiness standards.
answerB: source from which the part came.
answerC: product or material was not produced under an FAA production approval.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Any product, part, or material installed on a type certificate product must meet FAA airworthiness standards.

question: A Technical Standard Order (TSO) is issued by whom?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: TSOs are issued by the Administrator under 14 CFR Part 21.

question: What is the opposition to the flow of AC produced by an electromagnetic field (EMF) with generated back voltage called?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Alternating current is in a constant state of change; EMF causes continuously inducted voltage opposition to the current in the circuit. This opposition is called inductive reactance (X(L)), and is measured in ohms just as resistance is measured. Inductance is the property of a circuit to oppose any change in current and is measured in henries. Inductive reactance is a measure of how much the countering EMF in the circuit will oppose current variations.

question: Electrostatic fields are also known as
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A field of force exists around a charged body. This is an electrostatic field (sometimes called a dielectric field) and it is represented by lines that extend in all directions from the charged body which terminate where there is an equal and opposite charge.

question: In a parallel circuit with three 6-ohm resistors across a 12-volt battery, what is the total current (It) value in the circuit?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The total resistance of this circuit is 2 ohms. The total current flowing in this circuit is 6 amps.

question: In a parallel circuit with four 6-ohm resistors across a 24-volt battery, what is the total voltage across resistor-three (VR3) in the circuit?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: In a parallel circuit the source or battery voltage is applied to each of the individual resistors.

question: Which of the following logic gates will provide an active high out only when all inputs are different?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The output of the XOR gate will only be at an active high when one and only one of the two inputs is high. If both inputs are low, or both inputs are high, then the output of the gate will be low.

question: Which of the following best describes the operating principal in a nickel-cadmium battery installed in an aircraft?
answerA: At full charge, the electrolyte will be at its lowest level and should be filled.
answerB: To completely charge a nickel-cadmium battery, some gassing must take place; thus, some water will be used.
answerC: When positive plates slowly give up oxygen, which is regained by the negative plates, the battery is charging.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Toward the end of the charging cycle, the cells emit gas. This will also occur if the cells are overcharged. This gas is caused by decomposition of the water in the electrolyte into hydrogen at the negative plates and oxygen at the positive plates. To completely charge a nickel-cadmium battery, some gassing, however slight, must take place; thus, some water will be used.

question: What metal has special short-time heat properties and is used in the construction of aircraft firewalls?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Titanium has some merit for short-time exposure up to 3,000 degrees F where strength is not important. Aircraft firewalls demand this requirement.

question: Rolling-type flaring tools are used to flare X, X, and X tubing.
answerA: Stainless steel, hard copper, mild steel.
answerB: Titanium, soft copper, corrosion resistant steel.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Use rolling-type flaring tools only to flare soft copper, aluminum, and brass tubing. Do not use with corrosion resistant steel or titanium.

question: What type of drawing line consists of alternating long and short lines?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Centerlines are made up of alternate long and short dashes. They indicate the center of an object or part of an object. Where centerlines cross, the short dashes intersect symmetrically. In the case of very small circles, the centerlines may be shown unbroken.

question: Convert 7 to binary form.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: To convert a decimal number to a binary number, the place values in the binary system are used to create a sum of numbers that equal the value of the decimal number being converted. Start with the largest binary place value and subtract from the decimal number. Continue this process until all of the binary digits are determined. 7 = 0111 in binary.

question: What is meant by the term "residual fuel"?
answerA: A known amount of fuel left in the tanks, lines, and engine.
answerB: The fuel remaining in the tanks, lines, and engine after draining.
answerC: The fuel remaining in the tank, lines, and engine before draining.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: When weighing an aircraft to determine its empty weight, only the weight of residual (unusable) fuel should be included. Residual fuel is the fluid that will not normally drain out because it is trapped in the fuel lines and tanks.

question: When calculating the new weight and balance for an aircraft, what is used to determine the operating CG range?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Some of the important weight and balance information found in a Type Certificate Data Sheet is as follows: center of gravity range, maximum weight, leveling means, number of seats and location, baggage capacity, fuel capacity, datum location, engine horsepower, oil capacity, amount of fuel in empty weight, and amount of oil in empty weight.

question: If a fire develops in an engine during the starting procedure, you should
answerA: discontinue the start attempt and allow the fireguard to extinguish the fire.
answerB: continue cranking to start the engine and extinguish the fire.
answerC: continue cranking and allow the fireguard to extinguish the fire.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: If an engine fire develops during the starting procedure, continue cranking to start the engine and blow out the fire. If the engine does not start and the fire continues to burn, discontinue the start attempt. The fireguard should extinguish the fire using the available equipment.

question: Examples of units used in the conventional (U.S. or English) measurement include
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Some of the conventional U.S. or English units of measure are: inches, feet, yards, miles, ounces, pints, gallons, and pounds.

question: The main rotor system on a helicopter is classified in three groups. Which of those listed is NOT one of these groups?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The classification of main rotor systems is based on how the blades move relative to the main rotor hub. The principal classifications are known as fully articulated, semi-rigid, and rigid.

question: What does the acronym TSO mean regarding a type certificated aircraft part, material, component and/or process?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A Technical Standard Order (TSO) is an approval for the manufacture of a component for use on certificated aircraft.

question: 14 CFR Part 65 contains regulations regarding the certification of
answerA: pilots, flight Instructors, and ground instructors.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR Part 65, "Certification: Airmen Other Than Flight Crewmembers," prescribes the requirements for the issuance of mechanic certificates and associated ratings, air traffic control operators, aircraft dispatchers, repairmen, and parachute riggers and the general operating rules for the holders of these certificates and ratings.

question: If each cell, connected in series, equals 2 volts, how would a 12-cell lead acid battery be rated?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The voltage of a battery is determined by the number of cells connected in series to form the battery. Although the voltage of one lead-acid cell just removed from a charger is approximately 2.2 volts, a lead-acid cell is normally rated at approximately 2 volts. A battery rated at 12 volts consists of 6 lead-acid cells connected in series, and a battery rated at 24 volts is composed of 12 cells.

question: Self-locking nuts may be used on aircraft provided that
answerA: the head of the bolt is safety wired.
answerB: they are installed with a lock washer.
answerC: the bolt or nut is not subject to rotation.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Self-locking nuts are used on aircraft to provide tight connections which will not shake loose under severe vibration. Do not use self-locking nuts at joints that subject either the nut or bolt to rotation.

question: What factors strengthen a coil inductor?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: As more loops are added close together, the strength of the magnetic field increases. Many loops close together will result in a strong electromagnet.

question: What is ATA iSpec 2200?
answerA: Standardized electronic documentation for aircraft models.
answerC: Airline transport catalog for aircraft parts.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: ATA iSpec 2200 is a compilation of what used to be ATA Spec 100 and ATA Spec 2100. This ATA iSpec 2200 standardizes the format in which maintenance information is presented in aircraft maintenance manuals, and makes it available in electronic format.

question: What regulations are covered by 14 CFR Part 1?
answerA: Certification of airmen other than crewmembers.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR part 1 covers definitions and abbreviations. This regulation is helpful for learning the legal terms and their associated meanings as well as the many acronyms used in aviation.

question: Which of the following is an instance when a special flight permit may not be issued?
answerA: Flying passengers on a scheduled operation.
answerB: Flying the aircraft to a location where repairs or maintenance can be performed.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: A special flight permit may be issued for an aircraft that may not currently meet applicable airworthiness requirements but is capable of safe flight, for the following purposes:|1. Flying the aircraft to a base where repairs, alterations, or maintenance are to be performed, or to a point of storage.|2. Delivering or exporting the aircraft.|3. Production flight testing new production aircraft.|4. Evacuating aircraft from areas of impending danger.|5. Conducting customer demonstration flights in new production aircraft that have satisfactorily completed production flight tests.|6. Operating an aircraft at a weight in excess of its maximum certificated takeoff weight under specific circumstances.|To request a special flight permit, the applicant must submit to the FAA: the purpose of the flight, the proposed itinerary, the crew required to operate the aircraft and its equipment, the ways in which the aircraft does not comply with the applicable airworthiness requirements, any restrictions the FAA deems necessary for the purpose of prescribing operating limitations. Flying passengers on a scheduled operation is not one of the allowed reasons for a special flight permit.

question: The advantages of HI-LOK(tm) fasteners include
answerA: light weight, high fatigue resistance, high strength, and inability to be over-torqued.
answerB: light weight, high fatigue resistance, high strength, and ease of removal and reuse.
answerC: light weight, high damage tolerance, high strength, and inability to be over-torqued.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The advantages of HI-LOK(tm) two-piece fastener include its light weight, high fatigue resistance, high strength, and its inability to be over-torqued.

question: Which of the following statements is correct?
answerA: When the cyclic pitch control lever is raised, the blade angle of all the rotor blades increases uniformly and they create the lift that allows the helicopter to take off vertically.
answerB: When the collective pitch control lever is raised, the blade angle of all the rotor blades increases uniformly and they create the lift that allows the helicopter to take off vertically.
answerC: When the collective pitch control lever is raised, the blade angle of the aft rotor blades decreases uniformly and they create the lift that allows the helicopter to take off vertically.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The primary flight controls on a helicopter are the collective and cyclic control levers and anti-torque pedals. When the collective pitch control lever is raised, the blade angle of all the rotor blades increases uniformly and they create the lift that allows the helicopter to take off vertically.  The cyclic pitch control lever, like the yoke of an airplane, can be pulled back or pushed forward (for backward or forward motion), and can be moved left and right (to bank left or right).

question: What does the letter Q symbolize when measuring electrical charge?
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: The general formula for capacitance in terms of charge and voltage is C = Q/E, where:|C = Capacitance measured in farads|E = Applied voltage measured in volts|Q = Charge measured in coulombs._x000D_

question: When installing a castle nut, and the nut castellation does not align with the cotter pin hole in the bolt within the torque range, the acceptable practice is to
answerA: back the nut off and align it to the nearest hole.
answerB: continue tightening the nut to the next hole.
answerC: change the nut or washer and try again.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: When tightening castellated nuts on bolts, the cotter pin holes may not line up with the slots in the nuts for the range of recommended values. Except in cases of highly-stressed engine parts, the nut may not be over-torqued. Remove hardware and realign the holes.

question: (Refer to Figure 67). Solve the equation.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Follow the order of operations rule:|Square Root 31 + Square Root 43 = 5.56 + 6.56 = 12.12|12.12 / 172 = 12.12 / 289 = 0.042_x000D_

question: (Refer to Figure 68.) Which results in the largest number?
14 CFR Part 65 Subpart D contains regulations regarding the certification of
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: 14 CFR Part 65, "Certification: Airmen Other Than Flight Crewmembers," prescribes the requirements for the issuance of mechanic certificates and associated ratings, air traffic control operators, aircraft dispatchers, repairmen, and parachute riggers and the general operating rules for the holders of these certificates and ratings. Subpart D specifically covers mechanics. Subpart E specifically covers repairman. Pilot certification is covered in 14 CFR Part 61.

question: When installing a castle nut, start alignment with the cotter pin hole at the
answerA: minimum recommended torque without friction drag torque.
answerB: maximum recommended torque minus friction drag torque.
answerC: minimum recommended torque plus friction drag torque.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: When installing a castle nut, start alignment with the cotter pin hole at the minimum recommended torque plus friction drag torque. Do not exceed the maximum torque plus the friction drag. If the hole and nut castellation do not align, change washer or nut and try again.

question: What schematic symbol represents a current limiter?
answerA: A triangle and a Z-like symbol across a horizontal line.
answerB: One triangle pointing to a vertical line.
answerC: Two triangles pointing to each other with a line on both sides of the triangles.
explanationCommonToAllAnswerStems: Two triangles pointing to each other with a line on both sides of the triangles represents a current limiter. Current limiters are used primarily to sectionalize an aircraft circuit or bus.
